dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: People think ride-hailing is cheaper than owning a car, but actually the NHTSA study says city dwellers pay $15,500 a year on average for those services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: People think ride-hailing is cheaper than owning a car, but actually the N H T S A study says city dwellers pay fifteen thousand, five hundred dollars a year on average for those services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats according to a recent study conducted by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety in Orlando, FL. Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's just for economy-level, single rider trips—it doesn't even include things like surge pricing or tips.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's just for economy-level, single rider trips-it doesn't even include things like surge pricing or tips.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and when you compare that to AAA's estimate of $9,800 a year for a new car, it seems like a no-brainer, right? But then you have to factor in parking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and when you compare that to A A A's estimate of nine thousand, eight hundred dollars a year for a new car, it seems like a no-brainer, right? But then you have to factor in parking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Like in Chicago, parking alone averages $6,000 a year. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Like in Chicago, parking alone averages six thousand dollars a year. That's huge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But if you get free parking, suddenly owning a car becomes way more competitive—even cheaper than ride-hailing for some people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But if you get free parking, suddenly owning a car becomes way more competitive-even cheaper than ride-hailing for some people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, car owners who have access to free parking come out ahead big time on the deal, paying three times less than ride-hailers for their daily transportation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the study pointed out that in Austin, Texas, ride-hailing costs are through the roof—over $31,000 a year!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the study pointed out that in Austin, Texas, ride-hailing costs are through the roof-over thirty one thousand dollars a year!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's insane. Meanwhile, Denver came in as the cheapest among the cities they looked at, at $12,400.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's insane. Meanwhile, Denver came in as the cheapest among the cities they looked at, at twelve thousand, four hundred dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Urbanites in Dallas, TX pay the least among the 20 busiest U.S. cities for ride-hailing at $16,944 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But even then, if you own something like a hybrid SUV, you're looking at around $6,200 a year for 8,000 miles of driving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But even then, if you own something like a hybrid S U V, you're looking at around six thousand, two hundred dollars a year for eight thousand miles of driving.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, uh, way less than even the lowest ride-hailing cost. So for most people, driving your own car still wins financially.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, uh, way less than even the lowest ride-hailing cost. So for most people, driving your own car still wins financially.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Unless, you know, you barely drive or can't drive for health reasons. Then ride-hailing makes sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unless, you know, you barely drive or can't drive for health reasons. Then ride-hailing makes sense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Travis Kalanick from Uber kind of admitted that too—convenient, but not always cheaper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Travis Kalanick from Uber kind of admitted that too-convenient, but not always cheaper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With Kalanick Gone, Uber's Great Reset Can Begin Travis Kalanick is out at Uber despite de facto control of the Board of Dir...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he said "the car is still king" for most folks. Hard to argue with the numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he said the car is still king for most folks. Hard to argue with the numbers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for everyone else: the car is still king. Jim Gorzelany, Contributor

HostB: But even then, if you own something like a hybrid SUV, you’re looking at around $6,200 a year for 8,000 miles of driving.
HostA: Which is, uh, way less than even the lowest ride-hailing cost. So for most people, driving your own car still wins financially.
HostB: Unless, you know, you barely drive or can’t drive for health reasons. Then ride-hailing makes sense.
